trans-unit.source: Provides a collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> objects for use by a Windows Forms application.
Some of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursor> objects in this class can take on a different appearance than those described.
The user can change the cursor appearance by adjusting the mouse pointer settings in their operating system.
The panning and no move cursors are static and cannot be changed by the operating system.
The panning and no move cursors are used during mouse wheel operations.
Depending on the direction the window can be scrolled, the cursor changes to the appropriate no move cursor when the mouse wheel is clicked.
The cursor then changes to the appropriate panning cursor as the mouse is moved.
Gets the cursor that appears when an application starts.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears when an application starts.
Gets the arrow cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the arrow cursor.
Gets the crosshair cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the crosshair cursor.
Gets the default cursor, which is usually an arrow cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the default cursor.
Gets the hand cursor, typically used when hovering over a Web link.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the hand cursor.
Gets the Help cursor, which is a combination of an arrow and a question mark.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the Help cursor.
Gets the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a horizontal splitter bar.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a horizontal splitter bar.
Gets the I-beam cursor, which is used to show where the text cursor appears when the mouse is clicked.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the I-beam cursor.
Gets the cursor that indicates that a particular region is invalid for the current operation.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that indicates that a particular region is invalid for the current operation.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in both a horizontal and vertical direction.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in a horizontal direction.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in a vertical direction.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the right.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the right.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the right.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the right.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in an upward direction.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in an upward direction.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the left.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the left.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the right.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the right.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in a downward direction.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in a downward direction.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the left.

The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the left.
Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the left.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the left.
Gets the four-headed sizing cursor, which consists of four joined arrows that point north, south, east, and west.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the four-headed sizing cursor.
Gets the two-headed diagonal (northeast/southwest) sizing cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents two-headed diagonal (northeast/southwest) sizing cursor.
Gets the two-headed vertical (north/south) sizing cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the two-headed vertical (north/south) sizing cursor.
Gets the two-headed diagonal (northwest/southeast) sizing cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the two-headed diagonal (northwest/southeast) sizing cursor.
Gets the two-headed horizontal (west/east) sizing cursor.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the two-headed horizontal (west/east) sizing cursor.
Gets the up arrow cursor, typically used to identify an insertion point.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the up arrow cursor.
Gets the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a vertical splitter bar.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a vertical splitter bar.
Gets the wait cursor, typically an hourglass shape.
To force display of the wait cursor over a given control, call that control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.UseWaitCursor%2A> method.

To make the wait cursor display for the entire application, regardless of the control or form selected, call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application.UseWaitCursor%2A> on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application> class.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref> that represents the wait cursor.
